member.name: T:IrrlichtLime.Scene.AnimatedMeshSceneNode
member.summary:
Scene node capable of displaying an animated mesh and its shadow.
The shadow is optional: if a shadow should be displayed too, just invoke the AddShadowVolumeSceneNode().

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.AnimatedMeshSceneNode.AddShadowVolumeSceneNode
member.summary:
Creates shadow volume scene node as child of this node.
The shadow can be rendered using the ZPass or the zfail method. ZPass is a little bit faster because the shadow volume creation is easier, but with this method there occur ugly looking artifacs when the camera is inside the shadow volume. These error do not occur with the ZFail method.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.AnimatedMeshSceneNode.AddShadowVolumeSceneNode(IrrlichtLime.Scene.Mesh)
member.summary:
Creates shadow volume scene node as child of this node.
The shadow can be rendered using the ZPass or the zfail method. ZPass is a little bit faster because the shadow volume creation is easier, but with this method there occur ugly looking artifacs when the camera is inside the shadow volume. These error do not occur with the ZFail method.
member.param: Optional custom mesh for shadow volume. If null base mesh is used. Default is null.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.AnimatedMeshSceneNode.AddShadowVolumeSceneNode(IrrlichtLime.Scene.Mesh,System.Int32)
member.summary:
Creates shadow volume scene node as child of this node.
The shadow can be rendered using the ZPass or the zfail method. ZPass is a little bit faster because the shadow volume creation is easier, but with this method there occur ugly looking artifacs when the camera is inside the shadow volume. These error do not occur with the ZFail method.
member.param: Optional custom mesh for shadow volume. If null base mesh is used. Default is null.
Id of the shadow scene node. This id can be used to identify the node later. Default is -1.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.AnimatedMeshSceneNode.AddShadowVolumeSceneNode(IrrlichtLime.Scene.Mesh,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Creates shadow volume scene node as child of this node.
The shadow can be rendered using the ZPass or the zfail method. ZPass is a little bit faster because the shadow volume creation is easier, but with this method there occur ugly looking artifacs when the camera is inside the shadow volume. These error do not occur with the ZFail method.
member.param: Optional custom mesh for shadow volume. If null base mesh is used. Default is null.
Id of the shadow scene node. This id can be used to identify the node later. Default is -1.
If set to true, the shadow will use the zfail method, if not, zpass is used. Default is true.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.AnimatedMeshSceneNode.AddShadowVolumeSceneNode(IrrlichtLime.Scene.Mesh,System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Single)
member.summary:
Creates shadow volume scene node as child of this node.
The shadow can be rendered using the ZPass or the zfail method. ZPass is a little bit faster because the shadow volume creation is easier, but with this method there occur ugly looking artifacs when the camera is inside the shadow volume. These error do not occur with the ZFail method.
member.param: Optional custom mesh for shadow volume. If null base mesh is used. Default is null.
Id of the shadow scene node. This id can be used to identify the node later. Default is -1.
If set to true, the shadow will use the zfail method, if not, zpass is used. Default is true.

Value used by the shadow volume algorithm to scale the shadow volume (for zfail shadow volume we support only finite shadows, so camera zfar must be larger than shadow back cap, which is depend on infinity parameter). Default is 1000.0f.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.AnimatedMeshSceneNode.GetJointNode(System.Int32)
member.summary:
Get a joint in the mesh (if the mesh is a bone based mesh).
With this method it is possible to attach scene nodes to joints for example possible to attach a weapon to the left hand of an animated model. For example: "yourAnimatedMeshSceneNode.GetJointNode("LeftHand").AddChild(weaponSceneNode);"
Please note that the joint returned by this method may not exist before this call and the joints in the node were created by it.
member.param: Index of the joint.
member.returns: The scene node which represents the joint with the specified index. Returns null if the contained mesh is not an skinned mesh or the index of the joint could not be found.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.AnimatedMeshSceneNode.GetJointNode(System.String)
member.summary:
Get a joint in the mesh (if the mesh is a bone based mesh).
With this method it is possible to attach scene nodes to joints for example possible to attach a weapon to the left hand of an animated model. For example: "yourAnimatedMeshSceneNode.GetJointNode("LeftHand").AddChild(weaponSceneNode);"
Please note that the joint returned by this method may not exist before this call and the joints in the node were created by it.
member.param: Name of the joint.
member.returns: The scene node which represents the joint with the specified name. Returns null if the contained mesh is not an skinned mesh or the name of the joint could not be found.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.AnimatedMeshSceneNode.SetMD2Animation(System.String)
member.summary:
Starts a default MD2 animation.
With this method it is easily possible to start a Run, Attack, Die or whatever animation, if the mesh contained in this scene node is an MD2 mesh. Otherwise, nothing happens.
This method uses a character string to identify the animation. If the animation is a standard md2 animation, you might want to start this animation with the AnimationTypeMD2 enumeration instead.
member.param: Name of the animation which should be played.
member.returns: True if successful, and false if not, for example if the mesh in the scene node is not an MD2 mesh, or no animation with this name could be found.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.AnimatedMeshSceneNode.SetMD2Animation(IrrlichtLime.Scene.AnimationTypeMD2)
member.summary:
Starts a default MD2 animation.
With this method it is easily possible to start a Run, Attack, Die or whatever animation, if the mesh contained in this scene node is an MD2 mesh. Otherwise, nothing happens.
member.param: An MD2 animation type, which should be played.
member.returns: True if successful, and false if not, for example if the mesh in the scene node is not an MD2 mesh.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.AnimatedMeshSceneNode.SetRenderFromIdentity(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Enables or disables rendering mesh ignoring its transformation. Culling is unaffected.
member.param: True to enable the state or false to disable.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.AnimatedMeshSceneNode.SetTransitionTime(System.Single)
member.summary:
Sets the transition time.
Note: This needs to enable joints, and call SetJointMode(JointUpdateOnRender.Control). You must call AnimateJoints(), or the mesh will not animate.
member.param: New transition time in seconds.

member.summary: The keyboard mapping for this animator.

member.summary: The speed of movement in units per millisecond.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CameraFPSSceneNodeAnimator.RotateSpeed
member.summary:
The rotation speed in degrees.
The degrees are equivalent to a half screen movement of the mouse, i.e. if the mouse cursor had been moved to the border of the screen since the last animation.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CameraFPSSceneNodeAnimator.SetInvertMouse(System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Sets whether the Y axis of the mouse should be inverted.
If enabled then moving the mouse down will cause the camera to look up. It is disabled by default.
member.param: True if Y axis of mouse should be inverted.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CameraFPSSceneNodeAnimator.SetVerticalMovement(System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Sets whether vertical movement should be allowed.
If vertical movement is enabled then the camera may fight with gravity causing camera shake. Disable this if the camera has a collision animator with gravity enabled.
member.param: True if vertical movement should be allowed.

member.name: T:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CameraMayaSceneNodeAnimator
member.summary:
Special scene node animator for Maya-style cameras.
The camera is moving relative to the target with the mouse, by pressing either of the three buttons. In order to move the camera, set a new target for the camera. The distance defines the current orbit radius the camera moves on. Distance can be changed via the setter or by mouse events.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CameraMayaSceneNodeAnimator.Distance
member.summary: The current distance, i.e. orbit radius.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CameraMayaSceneNodeAnimator.MoveSpeed
member.summary: The speed of movement.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CameraMayaSceneNodeAnimator.RotateSpeed
member.summary: The rotation speed.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CameraMayaSceneNodeAnimator.ZoomSpeed
member.summary: The zoom speed.

member.name: T:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CameraSceneNode
member.summary:
Scene Node which is a (controlable) camera.
The whole scene will be rendered from the cameras point of view. Because the CameraScenNode is a SceneNode, it can be attached to any other scene node, and will follow its parents movement, rotation and so on.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CameraSceneNode.AspectRatio
member.summary: The aspect ratio of the camera.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CameraSceneNode.FarValue
member.summary: The value of the far clipping plane of the camera. Default is 2000.0f.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CameraSceneNode.FOV
member.summary: The field of view of the camera in radians.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CameraSceneNode.InputReceiverEnabled
member.summary: If this is set to true, the camera will respond to key and mouse inputs.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CameraSceneNode.NearValue
member.summary: The value of the near clipping plane of the camera. Default is 1.0f.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CameraSceneNode.Orthogonal
member.summary: True if a camera is orthogonal.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CameraSceneNode.ProjectionMatrix
member.summary: The current projection matrix of the camera.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CameraSceneNode.Rotation
member.summary:
Rotation of the node in degrees.
This only modifies the relative rotation of the node. If the camera's target and rotation are bound (see TargetAndRotationBinding) then setting this property will also change the camera's scene node rotation to match the target.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CameraSceneNode.SetProjectionMatrix(IrrlichtLime.Core.Matrix)
member.summary:
Sets the projection matrix of the camera.
The Matrix class has some methods to build a projection matrix. e.g: Matrix4.BuildProjectionMatrixPerspectiveFovLH. Note that the matrix will only stay as set by this method until you explicitly set one of the following properties: NearValue, FarValue, AspectRatio or FOV.
member.param: The new projection matrix of the camera.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CameraSceneNode.SetProjectionMatrix(IrrlichtLime.Core.Matrix,System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Sets the projection matrix of the camera.
The Matrix class has some methods to build a projection matrix. e.g: Matrix4.BuildProjectionMatrixPerspectiveFovLH. Note that the matrix will only stay as set by this method until you explicitly set one of the following properties: NearValue, FarValue, AspectRatio or FOV.
member.param: The new projection matrix of the camera.
Set this to true if the matrix is an orthogonal one (e.g. from Matrix.BuildProjectionMatrixOrtho). Default is false.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CameraSceneNode.Target
member.summary:
Look at target of the camera, in world co-ordinates.
If the camera's target and rotation are bound (see TargetAndRotationBinding) then setting this property will also change the camera's scene node rotation to match the target. Note that thevalue is the current absolute position internally, so if you changed Position since last rendering you must call UpdateAbsolutePosition() before setting this value.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CameraSceneNode.TargetAndRotationBinding
member.summary:
True if the camera scene node's rotation and its target position are bound together.
When bound, setting Rotation will update the camera's target position to be along its +Z axis, and likewise setting Target will update its rotation so that its +Z axis will point at the target point. FPS camera use this binding by default; other cameras do not.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CameraSceneNode.UpVector
member.summary: The up vector of the camera.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CameraSceneNode.ViewFrustum
member.summary: The current view frustum.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CameraSceneNode.ViewMatrix
member.summary: The current view matrix of the camera.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CameraSceneNode.ViewMatrixAffector
member.summary:
Custom view matrix affector.
This matrix will be multiplied with the view matrix when it gets updated. This allows for custom camera setups like, for example, a reflection camera.

member.name: T:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CollisionResponseSceneNodeAnimator
member.summary:
Special scene node animator for doing automatic collision detection and response.
This scene node animator can be attached to any single scene node and will then prevent it from moving through specified collision geometry (e.g. walls and floors of the) world, as well as having it fall under gravity. This animator provides a simple implementation of first person shooter cameras. Attach it to a camera, and the camera will behave as the player control in a first person shooter game: The camera stops and slides at walls, walks up stairs, falls down if there is no floor under it, and so on.
The animator will treat any change in the position of its target scene node as movement, including setting Position, as movement. If you want to teleport the target scene node manually to a location without it being effected by collision geometry, then set TargetNode after setting node.Position.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CollisionResponseSceneNodeAnimator.AnimateTarget
member.summary: True if TargetNode should react on collision. Default is true.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CollisionResponseSceneNodeAnimator.CollisionNode
member.summary: The node that was collided with.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CollisionResponseSceneNodeAnimator.CollisionOccurred
member.summary: True if a collision occurred during the last call to AnimateNode().

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CollisionResponseSceneNodeAnimator.CollisionPoint
member.summary: The last point of collision.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CollisionResponseSceneNodeAnimator.CollisionResultPosition
member.summary:
The position that the TargetNode will be moved to, unless the collision is consumed in a callback.
If you have a collision callback registered, and it consumes the collision, then the node will ignore the collision and will not stop at this position. Instead, it will move fully to the position that caused the collision to occur.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CollisionResponseSceneNodeAnimator.CollisionTriangle
member.summary: The last triangle that caused a collision.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CollisionResponseSceneNodeAnimator.EllipsoidRadius
member.summary:
The radius of the ellipsoid for collision detection and response.
If you have a scene node, and you are unsure about how big the radius should be, you could use the following code to determine it: EllipsoidRadius = node.BoundingBox.MaxEdge - node.BoundingBox.Center;

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CollisionResponseSceneNodeAnimator.EllipsoidTranslation
member.summary:
The translation of the ellipsoid for collision detection.
By default, the ellipsoid for collision detection is created around the center of the scene node, which means that the ellipsoid surrounds it completely. If this is not what you want, you may specify a translation for the ellipsoid.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CollisionResponseSceneNodeAnimator.Falling
member.summary:
True if the attached scene node is falling.
Falling means that there is no blocking wall from the scene node in the direction of the gravity.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CollisionResponseSceneNodeAnimator.Gravity
member.summary:
The current vector of gravity.
A good example value would be Vector3Df(0,-100.0f,0) for letting gravity affect all object to fall down. For bigger gravity, make increase the length of the vector. You can disable gravity by setting it to Vector3Df(0,0,0).

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CollisionResponseSceneNodeAnimator.Jump(System.Single)
member.summary: 'Jump' the animator, by adding a jump speed opposite to its gravity.
member.param: The initial speed of the jump; the velocity will be opposite to this animator's Gravity vector.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CollisionResponseSceneNodeAnimator.TargetNode
member.summary:
The single node that this animator is acting on.
Setting this value will force the animator to update its last target position for the node, allowing setting Position to teleport the node through collision geometry.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.CollisionResponseSceneNodeAnimator.World
member.summary: The current triangle selector holding all triangles of the world with which the scene node may collide.

member.name: T:IrrlichtLime.Scene.DummyTransformationSceneNode
member.summary:
Dummy scene node for adding additional transformations to the scene graph.
This scene node does not render itself, and does not respond to setting Position, Rotation and Scale. Its just a simple scene node that takes a matrix as relative transformation, making it possible to insert any transformation anywhere into the scene graph. This scene node is for example used by the AnimatedMeshSceneNode for emulating joint scene nodes when playing skeletal animations.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.DummyTransformationSceneNode.RelativeTransformationMatrix
member.summary:
The current relative transformation matrix.
This is the matrix, this scene node uses instead of actual values of Position, Rotation and Scale.

member.name: T:IrrlichtLime.Scene.LightSceneNode
member.summary:
Scene node which is a dynamic light.
You can switch the light on and off by making it visible or not. It can be animated by ordinary scene node animators. If the light type is directional or spot, the direction of the light source is defined by the rotation of the scene node (assuming (0,0,1) as the local direction of the light).

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.LightSceneNode.CastShadows
member.summary:
True if light would cast shadows, else false.
Enabling this flag won't automatically cast shadows, the meshes will still need shadow scene nodes attached. But one can enable or disable distinct lights for shadow casting for performance reasons.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.LightSceneNode.LightData
member.summary: The light data associated with this LightSceneNode.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.LightSceneNode.LightType
member.summary: The current light type.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.LightSceneNode.Radius
member.summary:
The light's radius of influence.
Outside this radius the light won't lighten geometry and cast no shadows. Setting the radius will also influence the attenuation, setting it to (0,1/radius,0). If you want to override this behavior, set the attenuation after the radius.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.LightSceneNode.Visible
member.summary: True if the light should be enabled.

member.summary:
Flags the mesh as changed, reloads hardware buffers.
This method has to be called every time the vertices or indices have changed. Otherwise, changes won't be updated on the GPU in the next render cycle.
member.param: Hardware buffer type to flag dirty.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.Mesh.SetHardwareMappingHint(IrrlichtLime.Scene.HardwareMappingHint,IrrlichtLime.Scene.HardwareBufferType)
member.summary:
Sets the hardware mapping hint.
This methods allows to define optimization hints for the hardware. This enables, e.g., the use of hardware buffers on platforms that support this feature. This can lead to noticeable performance gains.
member.param: New mapping hint value.
Which buffer mappingHint refers to.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.Mesh.SetMaterialFlag(IrrlichtLime.Video.MaterialFlag,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sets a flag of all contained materials to a new value.
member.param: Flag to set in all materials.
New value of the flag.

member.name: T:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshBuffer
member.summary:
Holds a mesh with a single material.
A part of a Mesh which has the same material on each face of that group. Logical groups of a Mesh need not be put into separate mesh buffers, but can be. Separately animated parts of the mesh must be put into separate mesh buffers. Some mesh buffer implementations have limitations on the number of vertices the buffer can hold. In that case, logical grouping can help. Moreover, the number of vertices should be optimized for the GPU upload, which often depends on the type of gfx card. Typial figures are 1000-10000 vertices per buffer.
Since mesh buffers are used for drawing, and hence will be exposed to the driver, chances are high that they are grab()'ed from somewhere. It's therefore required to dynamically allocate mesh buffers which are passed to a video driver and only drop the buffer once it's not used in the current code block anymore.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshBuffer.Create(IrrlichtLime.Video.VertexType,IrrlichtLime.Video.IndexType)
member.summary: Creates new MeshBuffer object. You have to call Drop() after you don't need this object.
member.param: Type of vertices.
Type of indices.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshBuffer.Append(IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshBuffer)
member.summary: Appends another mesh buffer to this one.
member.param: Mesh buffer to append.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshBuffer.SetDirty(IrrlichtLime.Scene.HardwareBufferType)
member.summary:
Flags the mesh buffer as changed, reloads hardware buffers.
This method has to be called every time the vertices or indices have changed. Otherwise, changes won't be updated on the GPU in the next render cycle.
member.param: Hardware buffer type to flag dirty.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshBuffer.SetHardwareMappingHint(IrrlichtLime.Scene.HardwareMappingHint,IrrlichtLime.Scene.HardwareBufferType)
member.summary:
Sets the hardware mapping hint.
This methods allows to define optimization hints for the hardware. This enables, e.g., the use of hardware buffers on platforms that support this feature. This can lead to noticeable performance gains.
member.param: New mapping hint value.
Which buffer mappingHint refers to.

member.name: T:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshCache
member.summary:
The mesh cache stores already loaded meshes and provides an interface to them.
You can access it using device.SceneManager.MeshCache. All existing scene managers will return a pointer to the same mesh cache, because it is shared between them.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshCache.AddMesh(System.String,IrrlichtLime.Scene.AnimatedMesh)
member.summary:
Adds a mesh to the internal list of loaded meshes.
Usually, SceneManager.GetMesh() is called to load a mesh from a file. That method searches the list of loaded meshes if a mesh has already been loaded and returns a pointer to if it is in that list and already in memory. Otherwise it loads the mesh. With this method it is possible to pretend that a mesh already has been loaded. This method can be used for example by mesh loaders who need to load more than one mesh with one call. They can add additional meshes with this method to the scene manager. The COLLADA loader for example uses this method.
member.param: Unique mame of the mesh. When calling SceneManager.GetMesh() with this name it will return the mesh set by this method.
A mesh which will now be referenced by this name.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshCache.Clear
member.summary:
Clears meshes from the mesh cache.
Warning: If you have pointers to meshes that were loaded with SceneManager.GetMesh() and you did not grab them, then they may become invalid.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshCache.Clear(System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Clears meshes from the mesh cache.
Warning: If you have pointers to meshes that were loaded with SceneManager.GetMesh() and you did not grab them, then they may become invalid.
member.param: True if you need to clear meshes that are held in the mesh cache but not used anywhere else. Default is false.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshCache.GetMesh(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets a mesh based on its index number.
member.param: Index of the mesh. Must be from 0 to MeshCount-1.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshCache.GetMesh(System.String)
member.summary: Gets a mesh based on its name (often a filename).
member.param: Name of the mesh. Usually a filename.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshCache.GetMeshIndex(IrrlichtLime.Scene.Mesh)
member.summary: Gets current index number of the mesh or -1 when not found.
member.param: The mesh to search for.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshCache.GetMeshName(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the name of a loaded mesh.
member.param: Index of the mesh. Must be from 0 to MeshCount-1.
member.returns: The name if mesh was found and has a name, else the empty value.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshCache.GetMeshName(IrrlichtLime.Scene.Mesh)
member.summary: Gets the name of a loaded mesh.
member.param: The mesh to search for.
member.returns: The name if mesh was found and has a name, else the empty value.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshCache.IsMeshLoaded(System.String)
member.summary: Checks if a mesh was already loaded.
member.param: Name of the mesh. Usually a filename.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshCache.MeshCount
member.summary: Amount of loaded meshes in the cache.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshCache.RemoveMesh(IrrlichtLime.Scene.Mesh)
member.summary:
Removes the mesh from the cache.
After loading a mesh with SceneManager.GetMesh(), the mesh can be removed from the cache using this method, freeing a lot of memory.
member.param: The mesh which shall be removed.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshCache.RenameMesh(System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary:
Renames a loaded mesh.
Note that renaming meshes might change the ordering of the meshes, and so the index of the meshes as returned by GetMeshIndex() or taken by some methods will change.
member.param: Index of the mesh. Must be from 0 to MeshCount-1.
New name for the mesh.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshCache.RenameMesh(IrrlichtLime.Scene.Mesh,System.String)
member.summary:
Renames a loaded mesh.
Note that renaming meshes might change the ordering of the meshes, and so the index of the meshes as returned by GetMeshIndex() or taken by some methods will change.
member.param: Mesh to be renamed.
New name for the mesh.

member.name: T:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshLoader
member.summary:
Class which is able to load an animated mesh from a file.
If you want Irrlicht be able to load meshes of currently unsupported file formats (e.g. .cob), then implement this and add your new MeshLoader with SceneManager.AddExternalMeshLoader() to the engine.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshLoader.CreateMesh(IrrlichtLime.IO.ReadFile)
member.summary: Creates/loads an animated mesh from the file.
member.param: File handler to load the file from.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshLoader.IsALoadableFileExtension(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true if the file might be loaded by this class. This decision should be based on the file extension (e.g. ".cob") only.
member.param: Name of the file to test.

member.name: T:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshManipulator
member.summary:
An interface for easy manipulation of meshes.
Scale, set alpha value, flip surfaces, and so on. This exists for fixing problems with wrong imported or exported meshes quickly after loading. It is not intended for doing mesh modifications and/or animations during runtime.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshManipulator.CreateAnimatedMesh(IrrlichtLime.Scene.Mesh)
member.summary: Creates a new AnimatedMesh and adds the mesh to it.
member.param: Input mesh.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshManipulator.CreateAnimatedMesh(IrrlichtLime.Scene.Mesh,IrrlichtLime.Scene.AnimatedMeshType)
member.summary: Creates a new AnimatedMesh and adds the mesh to it.
member.param: Input mesh.
The type of the animated mesh to create. Default is Unknown.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshManipulator.CreateForsythOptimizedMesh(IrrlichtLime.Scene.Mesh)
member.summary:
Creates a mesh using vertex cache optimization according to the Forsyth paper. The function is thread-safe (read: you can optimize several meshes in different threads).
More information can be found at http://home.comcast.net/~tom_forsyth/papers/fast_vert_cache_opt.html.
member.param: Source mesh for the operation.

member.param: Mesh to copy.

member.summary: Creates a copy of the mesh, which will only consist of Vertex3DTangents vertices. This is useful if you want to draw tangent space normal mapped geometry because it calculates the tangent and binormal data which is needed there.
member.param: Input mesh.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshManipulator.CreateMeshWithTangents(IrrlichtLime.Scene.Mesh,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates a copy of the mesh, which will only consist of Vertex3DTangents vertices. This is useful if you want to draw tangent space normal mapped geometry because it calculates the tangent and binormal data which is needed there.
member.param: Input mesh.

The normals are recalculated if set, otherwise the original ones are kept. Note that keeping the normals may introduce inaccurate tangents if the normals are very different to those calculated from the faces. Default is false.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshManipulator.CreateMeshWithTangents(IrrlichtLime.Scene.Mesh,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates a copy of the mesh, which will only consist of Vertex3DTangents vertices. This is useful if you want to draw tangent space normal mapped geometry because it calculates the tangent and binormal data which is needed there.
member.param: Input mesh.

The normals are recalculated if set, otherwise the original ones are kept. Note that keeping the normals may introduce inaccurate tangents if the normals are very different to those calculated from the faces. Default is false.
The normals/tangents are smoothed across the meshbuffer's faces if this flag is set. Default is false.

Improved smoothing calculation used. Default is false.

member.summary: Creates a planar texture mapping.
member.param: Meshbuffer on which the operation is performed.
Resolution of the planar mapping in horizontal direction. This is the ratio between object space and texture space.
Resolution of the planar mapping in vertical direction. This is the ratio between object space and texture space.
The axis along which the texture is projected. The allowed values are 0 (X), 1(Y), and 2(Z).
Vector added to the vertex positions (in object coordinates).

member.name: T:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshSceneNode
member.summary: A scene node displaying a static mesh.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshSceneNode.AddShadowVolumeSceneNode
member.summary:
Adds shadow volume scene node as child of this node.
The shadow can be rendered using the ZPass or the ZFail method. ZPass is a little bit faster because the shadow volume creation is easier, but with this method there occur ugly looking artifacs when the camera is inside the shadow volume. These error do not occur with the ZFail method.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshSceneNode.AddShadowVolumeSceneNode(IrrlichtLime.Scene.Mesh)
member.summary:
Adds shadow volume scene node as child of this node.
The shadow can be rendered using the ZPass or the ZFail method. ZPass is a little bit faster because the shadow volume creation is easier, but with this method there occur ugly looking artifacs when the camera is inside the shadow volume. These error do not occur with the ZFail method.
member.param: Optional custom mesh for shadow volume. Default is null.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshSceneNode.AddShadowVolumeSceneNode(IrrlichtLime.Scene.Mesh,System.Int32)
member.summary:
Adds shadow volume scene node as child of this node.
The shadow can be rendered using the ZPass or the ZFail method. ZPass is a little bit faster because the shadow volume creation is easier, but with this method there occur ugly looking artifacs when the camera is inside the shadow volume. These error do not occur with the ZFail method.
member.param: Optional custom mesh for shadow volume. Default is null.
Id of the shadow scene node. Default is -1.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshSceneNode.AddShadowVolumeSceneNode(IrrlichtLime.Scene.Mesh,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Adds shadow volume scene node as child of this node.
The shadow can be rendered using the ZPass or the ZFail method. ZPass is a little bit faster because the shadow volume creation is easier, but with this method there occur ugly looking artifacs when the camera is inside the shadow volume. These error do not occur with the ZFail method.
member.param: Optional custom mesh for shadow volume. Default is null.
Id of the shadow scene node. Default is -1.
If true, the shadow will use the ZFail method, if not, ZPass is used. Default is true.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshSceneNode.AddShadowVolumeSceneNode(IrrlichtLime.Scene.Mesh,System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Single)
member.summary:
Adds shadow volume scene node as child of this node.
The shadow can be rendered using the ZPass or the ZFail method. ZPass is a little bit faster because the shadow volume creation is easier, but with this method there occur ugly looking artifacs when the camera is inside the shadow volume. These error do not occur with the ZFail method.
member.param: Optional custom mesh for shadow volume. Default is null.
Id of the shadow scene node. Default is -1.
If true, the shadow will use the ZFail method, if not, ZPass is used. Default is true.

Value used by the shadow volume algorithm to scale the shadow volume (for ZFail shadow volume we support only finite shadows, so camera' FarValue must be larger than shadow back cap, which is depend on infinity parameter). Default is 1000.0f.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshSceneNode.Mesh
member.summary: The currently defined mesh for display.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MeshSceneNode.ReadOnlyMeterials
member.summary:
Whether the materials are read-only.
If true the scene node should not copy the materials of the mesh but use them in a read-only style. In this way it is possible to change the materials of a mesh causing all mesh scene nodes referencing this mesh to change, too.

member.name: T:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MetaTriangleSelector
member.summary:
Interface for making multiple triangle selectors work as one big selector.
This is nothing more than a collection of one or more triangle selectors providing together the interface of one triangle selector. In this way, collision tests can be done with different triangle groups in one pass.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Scene.MetaTriangleSelector.RemoveTriangleSelector(IrrlichtLime.Scene.TriangleSelector)
member.summary: Removes a specific triangle selector from the collection.
member.param: Triangle selector which is in the list but will be removed.
member.returns: True if successful, false if not.

member.name: T:IrrlichtLime.Video.AntiAliasingMode
member.summary:
These flags are used to specify the anti-aliasing and smoothing modes.
Techniques supported are multisampling, geometry smoothing, and alpha to coverage. Some drivers don't support a per-material setting of the anti-aliasing modes. In those cases, FSAA/multisampling is defined by the device mode chosen upon creation via IrrlichtCreationParameters.

member.summary: Enhanced anti-aliasing for transparent materials.

member.summary: All typical anti-alias and smooth modes.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.AntiAliasingMode.LineSmooth
member.summary: Line smoothing.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.AntiAliasingMode.Off
member.summary: Use to turn off anti-aliasing for this material.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.AntiAliasingMode.PointSmooth
member.summary: point smoothing, often in software and slow, only with OpenGL.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.AntiAliasingMode.Quality
member.summary: High-quality anti-aliasing, not always supported, automatically enables Simple mode.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.AntiAliasingMode.Simple
member.summary: Default anti-aliasing mode.

member.name: T:IrrlichtLime.Video.Color
member.summary:
Class representing a 32 bit ARGB color.
The color values for alpha, red, green, and blue are stored in a single unsigned int. So all four values may be between 0 and 255. Alpha in Irrlicht is opacity, so 0 is fully transparent, 255 is fully opaque (solid). This class is used by most parts of the Irrlicht Engine to specify a color.
Another way is using the class Colorf, which stores the color values in 4 floats.

member.name: T:IrrlichtLime.Video.Colorf
member.summary:
Class representing a 128 bit color (using 4 floats).
The color values for red, green, blue and alpha are each stored in a 32 bit floating point variable. So all four values may be between 0.0f and 1.0f. Another, faster way to define colors is using the class Color, which stores the color values in a single 32 bit integer.

member.name: T:IrrlichtLime.Video.ColorFormat
member.summary: Enumeration of all color formats. A color format specifies how color information is stored.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.ColorFormat.A16B16G16R16F
member.summary:
64 bit floating point format. 16 bits are used for the red, green, blue and alpha channels.
Note: this format may only be used for render target textures.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.ColorFormat.A1R5G5B5
member.summary: 16 bit color format used by the software driver. There are 5 bits for every color component, and a single bit is left for alpha information.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.ColorFormat.A32B32G32R32F
member.summary:
128 bit floating point format. 32 bits are used for the red, green, blue and alpha channels.
Note: this format may only be used for render target textures.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.ColorFormat.A8R8G8B8
member.summary: Default 32 bit color format. 8 bits are used for every component: red, green, blue and alpha.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.ColorFormat.G16R16F
member.summary:
32 bit floating point format using 16 bits for the red channel and 16 bits for the green channel.
Note: this format may only be used for render target textures.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.ColorFormat.G32R32F
member.summary:
64 bit floating point format using 32 bits for the red channel and 32 bits for the green channel.
Note: this format may only be used for render target textures.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.ColorFormat.R16F
member.summary:
16 bit floating point format using 16 bits for the red channel.
Note: this format may only be used for render target textures.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.ColorFormat.R32F
member.summary:
32 bit floating point format using 32 bits for the red channel.
Note: this format may only be used for render target textures.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.ColorFormat.R5G6B5
member.summary: Standard 16 bit color format.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.ColorFormat.R8G8B8
member.summary: 24 bit color, no alpha channel, but 8 bit for red, green and blue.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.ColorFormat.Unknown
member.summary: Unknown color format.

The color values for hue, saturation and luminance are stored in 32 bit floating point variables. Hue is in range [0,360], Luminance and Saturation are in percent [0,100].

member.name: T:IrrlichtLime.Video.ColorMaterial
member.summary:
These flags allow to define the interpretation of vertex color when lighting is enabled.
Without lighting being enabled the vertex color is the only value defining the fragment color. Once lighting is enabled, the four values for diffuse, ambient, emissive, and specular take over. With these flags it is possible to define which lighting factor shall be defined by the vertex color instead of the lighting factor which is the same for all faces of that material. The default is to use vertex color for the diffuse value, another pretty common value is to use vertex color for both diffuse and ambient factor.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.ColorMaterial.Ambient
member.summary: Use vertex color for ambient light.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.ColorMaterial.Diffuse
member.summary: Use vertex color for diffuse light, this is default.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.ColorMaterial.DiffuseAndAmbient
member.summary: Use vertex color for both diffuse and ambient light.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.ColorMaterial.Emissive
member.summary: Use vertex color for emissive light.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.ColorMaterial.None
member.summary: Don't use vertex color for lighting.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.ColorMaterial.Specular
member.summary: Use vertex color for specular light.

member.name: T:IrrlichtLime.Video.DriverType
member.summary: Enumerates all supported driver types.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.DriverType.BurningsVideo
member.summary:
The Burning's Software Renderer, an alternative software renderer.
Basically it can be described as the Irrlicht Software renderer on steroids. It rasterizes 3D geometry perfectly: It is able to perform correct 3d clipping, perspective correct texture mapping, perspective correct color mapping, and renders sub pixel correct, sub texel correct primitives. In addition, it does bilinear texel filtering and supports more materials than the Software driver.
This renderer has been written entirely by Thomas Alten, thanks a lot for this huge contribution.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.DriverType.Direct3D8
member.summary:
Direct3D8 device, only available on Win32 platforms.
Performs hardware accelerated rendering of 3D and 2D primitives.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.DriverType.Direct3D9
member.summary:
Direct3D 9 device, only available on Win32 platforms.
Performs hardware accelerated rendering of 3D and 2D primitives.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.DriverType.Null
member.summary:
Null driver, useful for applications to run the engine without visualisation.
The null device is able to load textures, but does not render and display any graphics.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.DriverType.OpenGL
member.summary:
OpenGL device, available on most platforms.
Performs hardware accelerated rendering of 3D and 2D primitives.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.DriverType.Software
member.summary:
The Irrlicht Engine Software renderer.
Runs on all platforms, with every hardware. It should only be used for 2d graphics, but it can also perform some primitive 3d functions. These 3d drawing functions are quite fast, but very inaccurate, and don't even support clipping in 3D mode.

member.name: T:IrrlichtLime.Video.ExposedVideoData
member.summary:
Data describing a driver and operating system specific data.
This data can be retrived by VideoDriver.ExposedVideoData. Use this with caution. This only should be used to make it possible to extend the engine easily without modification of its source. Note: this class does not contain any valid data, if you are using the software or the null device.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.ExposedVideoData.DeviceContext
member.summary:
Device context.
Can be pointer to IDirect3D8, IDirect3D9 or HDC (private GDI device context) depends on the video driver.
Note: for software renderers this value is not valid.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Video.ExposedVideoData.#ctor
member.summary: Creates new instance.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.ExposedVideoData.RenderingContext
member.summary:
Rendering context.
Can be pointer to IDirect3DDevice8, IDirect3DDevice9 or HGLRC (permanent rendering context) depends on the video driver.
Note: for software renderers this value is not valid.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.ExposedVideoData.WindowID
member.summary:
Rendering window handle.
Note: for software renderers this value is not valid.

True to enable range-based vertex fog. The distance from the viewer is used to compute the fog, not the z-coordinate. This is better, but slower. This might not be available with all drivers and fog settings.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Video.GPUProgrammingServices.AddHighLevelShaderMaterial(System.String)
member.summary: Adds a new high-level shading material renderer to the VideoDriver.
member.param: The source of the vertex shader program. This can be null if no vertex program shall be used.
member.returns: Material type which can be set in Material.MaterialType to use the renderer. "(int)-1" is returned if an error occured, e.g. if a shader program could not be compiled or a compile target is not reachable. The error strings are then printed to the error log.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Video.GPUProgrammingServices.AddHighLevelShaderMaterial(System.String,System.String)
member.summary:
Adds a new high-level shading material renderer to the VideoDriver.
Convenience function for use with many defaults, without geometry shader. All shader names are set to "main" and compile targets are shader type 1.1.
member.param: The source of the vertex shader program. This can be null if no vertex program shall be used.
The source of the pixel shader program. This can be null if no pixel shader shall be used. Default: null.
member.returns: Material type which can be set in Material.MaterialType to use the renderer. "(int)-1" is returned if an error occured, e.g. if a shader program could not be compiled or a compile target is not reachable. The error strings are then printed to the error log.

member.summary: Adds a new high-level shading material renderer from file to the VideoDriver.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Video.GPUProgrammingServices.AddHighLevelShaderMaterialFromFiles(System.String,System.String)
member.summary:
Adds a new high-level shading material renderer from file to the VideoDriver.
Convenience function for use with many defaults, without geometry shader. All shader names are set to "main" and compile targets are shader type 1.1.
member.param: Text file containing the source of the vertex shader program. Set to empty string if no vertex shader shall be created. Default: empty string.
Text file containing the source of the pixel shader program. Set to empty string if no pixel shader shall be created. Default: empty string.
member.returns: Material type which can be set in Material.MaterialType to use the renderer. "(int)-1" is returned if an error occured, e.g. if a shader program could not be compiled or a compile target is not reachable. The error strings are then printed to the error log.

Text file containing the source of the geometry shader program. Set to empty string if no geometry shader shall be created. Default: empty string.
Name of the entry function of the geometryShaderFileName. Default: "main".
Geometry shader version the high level shader shall be compiled to. Default: GeometryShaderType.GS_4_0.
Type of vertices passed to geometry shader. Default: PrimitiveType.Triangles.
Type of vertices created by geometry shader. Default: PrimitiveType.TriangleStrip.
Maximal number of vertices created by geometry shader. If 0, maximal number supported is assumed. Default: 0.
Base material to use. Default: MaterialType.Solid.
member.returns: Material type which can be set in Material.MaterialType to use the renderer. "(int)-1" is returned if an error occured, e.g. if a shader program could not be compiled or a compile target is not reachable. The error strings are then printed to the error log.

member.summary: Adds a new high-level shading material renderer from file to the VideoDriver.

Type of vertices created by geometry shader. Default: PrimitiveType.TriangleStrip.
Maximal number of vertices created by geometry shader. If 0, maximal number supported is assumed. Default: 0.
Base material to use. Default: MaterialType.Solid.
User data. This int can be set to any value and will be set as parameter to your OnSetConstants event handler.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Video.GPUProgrammingServices.AddShaderMaterial(System.String)
member.summary:
Adds a new ASM shader material renderer to the VideoDriver.
Note that it is a good idea to call VideoDriver.QueryFeature() in advance to check if the VideoDriver supports the vertex and/or pixel shader version your are using.
member.param: String containing the source of the vertex shader program. This can be null if no vertex program shall be used. For DX8 programs, the will always input registers look like this: v0: position, v1: normal, v2: color, v3: texture cooridnates, v4: texture coordinates 2 if available. For DX9 programs, you can manually set the registers using the dcl_ statements.
member.returns: Material type which can be set in Material.MaterialType to use the renderer. "(int)-1" is returned if an error occured, e.g. if a shader program could not be compiled or a compile target is not reachable. The error strings are then printed to the error log.

For DX8 programs, the will always input registers look like this: v0: position, v1: normal, v2: color, v3: texture cooridnates, v4: texture coordinates 2 if available. For DX9 programs, you can manually set the registers using the dcl_ statements.
String containing the source of the pixel shader program. This can be null if you don't want to use a pixel shader. Default: null.

member.name: T:IrrlichtLime.Video.ImageLoader
member.summary:
Class which is able to create a image from a file.
If you want the Irrlicht Engine be able to load textures of currently unsupported file formats (e.g .gif), then implement this and add your new image loader with VideoDriver.AddExternalImageLoader() to the engine.
NOTE: currently Irrlicht Lime does not support extending engine with your own image loaders.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Video.ImageLoader.IsLoadableFileExtension(System.String)
member.summary:
Checks if the file might be loaded by this image loader.
Check is based on the file extension (e.g. ".tga").
member.param: Name of file to check.
member.returns: True if file seems to be loadable.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Video.ImageLoader.IsLoadableFileFormat(IrrlichtLime.IO.ReadFile)
member.summary:
Checks if the file might be loaded by this image loader.
Check might look into the file.
member.param: File to check.
member.returns: True if file seems to be loadable.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Video.ImageLoader.LoadImage(IrrlichtLime.IO.ReadFile)
member.summary: Loads an image from the file.
member.param: File to load from.
member.returns: Newly created image or null if error occured.

member.summary: 16 bit indexes.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.IndexType._32Bit

member.name: T:IrrlichtLime.Video.Light
member.summary:
Describes a dynamic point light.
Irrlicht Engine supports point lights, spot lights, and directional lights.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.Light.AmbientColor
member.summary: Ambient color emitted by the light.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.Light.Attenuation
member.summary:
Attenuation factors (constant, linear, quadratic).
Changes the light strength fading over distance. Can also be altered by setting the radius, Attenuation will change to (0,1.f/radius,0). Can be overridden after radius was set.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.Light.CastShadows
member.summary:
Indicate that the light casts shadows.
This value is ignored when set for LightSceneNode.SetLightData(), use LightSceneNode.CastShadows to set it.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.Light.DiffuseColor
member.summary:
Diffuse color emitted by the light.
This is the primary color you want to set.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.Light.Direction
member.summary:
Direction of the light.
If Type is LightType.Point, it is ignored.
This value is ignored when set for LightSceneNode.SetLightData(), use SceneNode.Rotation to set it.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.Light.Falloff
member.summary: The light strength's decrease between Outer and Inner cone.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.Light.InnerCone
member.summary: The angle of the spot's inner cone. Ignored for other types of light.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Video.Light.#ctor
member.summary: Constructs default light.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.Light.OuterCone
member.summary: The angle of the spot's outer cone. Ignored for other types of light.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.Light.Position
member.summary:
Position of the light.
If Type is LightType.Directional, it is ignored.
This value is ignored when set for LightSceneNode.SetLightData(), use SceneNode.Position to set it.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.Light.Radius
member.summary:
Radius of light. Everything within this radius will be lighted.
This value is ignored when set for LightSceneNode.SetLightData(), use LightSceneNode.Radius to set it.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.Light.SpecularColor
member.summary:
Specular color emitted by the light.
For details how to use specular highlights, see Material.Shininess.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.Light.Type
member.summary:
Type of the light.
This value is ignored when set for LightSceneNode.SetLightData(), use LightSceneNode.LightType to set it.

member.name: T:IrrlichtLime.Video.LightType
member.summary: Enumeration for different types of lights.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.LightType.Directional
member.summary: Directional light, coming from a direction from an infinite distance.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.LightType.Point
member.summary: Point light, it has a position in space and radiates light in all directions.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.LightType.Spot
member.summary: Spot light, it has a position in space, a direction, and a limited cone of influence.

member.name: T:IrrlichtLime.Video.Material

member.summary: Identity material. Equivalent to "new Material()".

member.summary: Identity material with disabled Lighting.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.Material.IdentityRedWireframe

member.summary: Maximum number of textures a Material can have.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.Material.AmbientColor

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.Material.AntiAliasing
member.summary: Antialiasing mode.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.Material.BackfaceCulling
member.summary: Is backface culling enabled? Default: true.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.Material.BlendOperation
member.summary: Defines blend operation. NOTE: the actual way to use this value is not yet determined, so ignore it for now.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.Material.ColorMask
member.summary: Defines the enabled color planes.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.Material.ColorMaterial
member.summary: Defines the interpretation of vertex color in the lighting equation. When lighting is enabled, vertex color can be used instead of the material values for light modulation. This allows to easily change e.g. the diffuse light behavior of each face. Default: ColorMaterial.Diffuse.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.Material.DiffuseColor
member.summary: How much diffuse light coming from a light source is reflected by this material.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.Material.EmissiveColor
member.summary: Light emitted by this material. Default is to emit no light.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.Material.Fog
member.summary: Is fog enabled? Default: false.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.Material.FrontfaceCulling
member.summary: Is frontface culling enabled? Default: false.

member.summary: Holds material parameters which exist per texture layer.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.MaterialLayer.AnisotropicFilter
member.summary:
Is anisotropic filtering enabled? Default: 0 (disabled).
In Irrlicht you can use anisotropic texture filtering in conjunction with bilinear or trilinear texture filtering to improve rendering results. Primitives will look less blurry with this flag switched on. The number gives the maximal anisotropy degree, and is often in the range 2-16. Value 1 is equivalent to 0, but should be avoided.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.MaterialLayer.BilinearFilter
member.summary: Is bilinear filtering enabled? Default: true.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.MaterialLayer.LODBias
member.summary:
Bias for the mipmap choosing decision.
This value can make the textures more or less blurry than with the default value of 0. The value (divided by 8.0f) is added to the mipmap level chosen initially, and thus takes a smaller mipmap for a region if the value is positive.

member.name: T:IrrlichtLime.Video.MaterialRenderer
member.summary:
Material renderer info.
Can be used to extend the engine with new materials. Refer to VideoDriver.AddMaterialRenderer() and GPUProgrammingServices.Add*() for more information on how to extend the engine with new materials.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.MaterialRenderer.Capability
member.summary:
The render capability of the material.
Because some more complex materials are implemented in multiple ways and need special hardware capabilities, it is possible to query how the current material renderer is performing on the current hardware.
0 if everything is running fine. Any other value is material renderer specific and means for example that the renderer switched back to a fall back material because it cannot use the latest shaders. More specific examples: Fixed function pipeline materials should return 0 in most cases, parallax mapped material will only return 0 when at least pixel shader 1.4 is available on that machine.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.MaterialRenderer.Transparent
member.summary:
True is the material is transparent.
The scene managment needs to know this for being able to sort the materials by opaque and transparent.

member.summary:
Can be called by a MaterialRenderer to make its work easier.
Sets all basic render states if needed. Basic render states are diffuse, ambient, specular, and emissive color, specular power, bilinear and trilinear filtering, wireframe mode, grouraudshading, lighting, zbuffer, zwriteenable, backfaceculling and fog enabling.
member.param: The new material to be used.
The material used until now.
Set to true if all renderstates should be set, regardless of their current state.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.MaterialRendererServices.VideoDriver
member.summary: Pointer to the VideoDriver.

member.name: T:IrrlichtLime.Video.MaterialType
member.summary: Abstracted and easy to use fixed function/programmable pipeline material modes.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.MaterialType.DetailMap
member.summary:
Detail mapped material.
The first texture is diffuse color map, the second is added to this and usually displayed with a bigger scale value so that it adds more detail. The detail map is added to the diffuse map using ADD_SIGNED, so that it is possible to add and substract color from the diffuse map. For example a value of (127,127,127) will not change the appearance of the diffuse map at all. Often used for terrain rendering.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.MaterialType.LightMap
member.summary:
Material type with standard lightmap technique.
There should be 2 textures: The first texture layer is a diffuse map, the second is a light map. Dynamic light is ignored.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.MaterialType.LightMapAdd
member.summary:
Material type with lightmap technique like MaterialType.LightMap.
But lightmap and diffuse texture are added instead of modulated.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.MaterialType.LightMapLighting
member.summary: Like MaterialType.LightMap, but also supports dynamic lighting.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.MaterialType.LightMapLightingM2
member.summary: Like MaterialType.LightMapM2, but also supports dynamic lighting.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.MaterialType.LightMapLightingM4
member.summary: Like MaterialType.LightMapM4, but also supports dynamic lighting.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.MaterialType.LightMapM2
member.summary:
Material type with standard lightmap technique.
There should be 2 textures: The first texture layer is a diffuse map, the second is a light map. Dynamic light is ignored. The texture colors are effectively multiplied by 2 for brightening. Like known in DirectX as D3DTOP_MODULATE2X.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.MaterialType.LightMapM4
member.summary:
Material type with standard lightmap technique.
There should be 2 textures: The first texture layer is a diffuse map, the second is a light map. Dynamic light is ignored. The texture colors are effectively multiplied by 4 for brightening. Like known in DirectX as D3DTOP_MODULATE4X.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.MaterialType.NormalMapSolid
member.summary:
A solid normal map renderer.
First texture is the color map, the second should be the normal map. Note that you should use this material only when drawing geometry consisting of vertices of type Vertex3DTangents (VertexType.Tangents). You can convert any mesh into this format using MeshManipulator.CreateMeshWithTangents(). This shader runs on vertex shader 1.1 and pixel shader 1.1 capable hardware and falls back to a fixed function lighted material if this hardware is not available. Only two lights are supported by this shader, if there are more, the nearest two are chosen.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.MaterialType.NormalMapTransparentAddColor
member.summary:
A transparent normal map renderer.
First texture is the color map, the second should be the normal map. Note that you should use this material only when drawing geometry consisting of vertices of type Vertex3DTangents (VertexType.Tangents). You can convert any mesh into this format using MeshManipulator.CreateMeshWithTangents(). This shader runs on vertex shader 1.1 and pixel shader 1.1 capable hardware and falls back to a fixed function lighted material if this hardware is not available. Only two lights are supported by this shader, if there are more, the nearest two are chosen.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.MaterialType.NormalMapTransparentVertexAlpha
member.summary:
A transparent (based on the vertex alpha value) normal map renderer.
First texture is the color map, the second should be the normal map. Note that you should use this material only when drawing geometry consisting of vertices of type Vertex3DTangents (VertexType.Tangents). You can convert any mesh into this format using MeshManipulator.CreateMeshWithTangents(). This shader runs on vertex shader 1.1 and pixel shader 1.1 capable hardware and falls back to a fixed function lighted material if this hardware is not available. Only two lights are supported by this shader, if there are more, the nearest two are chosen.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.MaterialType.OneTextureBlend
member.summary:
BlendFunc = source * sourceFactor + dest * destFactor (see BlendFactor enum).
Using only first texture. Generic blending method.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.MaterialType.ParallaxMapSolid
member.summary:
Just like MaterialType.NormalMapSolid, but uses parallax mapping.
Looks a lot more realistic. This only works when the hardware supports at least vertex shader 1.1 and pixel shader 1.4. First texture is the color map, the second should be the normal map. The normal map texture should contain the height value in the alpha component. The VideoDriver.MakeNormalMapTexture() method writes this value automatically when creating normal maps from a heightmap when using a 32 bit texture. The height scale of the material (affecting the bumpiness) is being controlled by the Material.MaterialTypeParam member. If set to zero, the default value (0.02f) will be applied. This value depends on with which scale the texture is mapped on the material. Too high or low values of Material.MaterialTypeParam can result in strange artifacts.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.MaterialType.ParallaxMapTransparentAddColor
member.summary:
A material like MaterialType.ParallaxMapSolid, but transparent.
Using MaterialType.TransparentAddColor as base material.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.MaterialType.ParallaxMapTransparentVertexAlpha
member.summary:
A material like MaterialType.ParallaxMapSolid, but transparent.
Using MaterialType.TransparentVertexAlpha as base material.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.MaterialType.Reflection2Layer
member.summary:
A reflecting material with an optional non reflecting texture layer.
The reflection map should be set as first texture.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.MaterialType.Solid
member.summary:
Standard solid material.
Only first texture is used, which is supposed to be the diffuse material.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.MaterialType.Solid2Layer
member.summary:
Solid material with 2 texture layers.
The second is blended onto the first using the alpha value of the vertex colors. This material is currently not implemented in OpenGL.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.MaterialType.SphereMap
member.summary:
Look like a reflection of the environment around it.
To make this possible, a texture called 'sphere map' is used, which must be set as the first texture.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.MaterialType.TransparentAddColor
member.summary:
A transparent material.
Only the first texture is used. The new color is calculated by simply adding the source color and the dest color. This means if for example a billboard using a texture with black background and a red circle on it is drawn with this material, the result is that only the red circle will be drawn a little bit transparent, and everything which was black is 100% transparent and not visible. This material type is useful for particle effects.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.MaterialType.TransparentAlphaChannel
member.summary:
Makes the material transparent based on the texture alpha channel.
The final color is blended together from the destination color and the texture color, using the alpha channel value as blend factor. Only first texture is used. If you are using this material with small textures, it is a good idea to load the texture in 32 bit mode (VideoDriver.SetTextureCreationFlag()). Also, an alpha ref is used, which can be manipulated using Material.MaterialTypeParam. This value controls how sharp the edges become when going from a transparent to a solid spot on the texture.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.MaterialType.TransparentAlphaChannelRef
member.summary:
Makes the material transparent based on the texture alpha channel.
If the alpha channel value is greater than 127, a pixel is written to the target, otherwise not. This material does not use alpha blending and is a lot faster than MaterialType.TransparentAlphaChannel. It is ideal for drawing stuff like leafes of plants, because the borders are not blurry but sharp. Only first texture is used. If you are using this material with small textures and 3d object, it is a good idea to load the texture in 32 bit mode (VideoDriver.SetTextureCreationFlag()).

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.MaterialType.TransparentReflection2Layer
member.summary:
A transparent reflecting material with an optional additional non reflecting texture layer.
The reflection map should be set as first texture. The transparency depends on the alpha value in the vertex colors. A texture which will not reflect can be set as second texture. Please note that this material type is currently not completely implemented in OpenGL.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.MaterialType.TransparentVertexAlpha
member.summary: Makes the material transparent based on the vertex alpha value.

member.name: T:IrrlichtLime.Video.Texture
member.summary:
Video driver dependent texture.
Texture can be created using VideoDriver.AddTexture() or VideoDriver.GetTexture(). After that, the texture may only be used by this VideoDriver. As you can imagine, textures of the DirectX and the OpenGL device will, e.g., not be compatible. An exception is the Software device and the NULL device, their textures are compatible. If you try to use a texture created by one device with an other device, the device will refuse to do that and write a warning or an error message to the log.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.Texture.AlphaChannel
member.summary: Texture has an alpha channel.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.Texture.ColorFormat
member.summary: Color format of the texture.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.Texture.DriverType
member.summary:
Gets driver type of the texture.
This is the driver, which created the texture. This method is used internally by the video devices, to check, if they may use a texture because textures may be incompatible between different devices.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Video.Texture.GetTexturePainter
member.summary:
Gets texture painter for this texture.
Note: you can use returned TexturePainter pointer as long as you sure that texture not dropped.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.Texture.MipMaps
member.summary: Texture has mip map levels.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.Texture.Name
member.summary: Name of the texture (in most cases this is the filename).

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.Texture.OriginalSize
member.summary:
Original size of the texture.
The texture is usually scaled, if it was created with an unoptimal size. For example if the size was not a power of two. This method returns the size of the texture it had before it was scaled. Can be useful when drawing 2d images on the screen, which should have the exact size of the original texture. Use Texture.Size if you want to know the real size it has now stored in the system.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.Texture.Pitch
member.summary:
Pitch of the texture (in bytes).
The pitch is the amount of bytes used for a row of pixels in a texture.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Video.Texture.RegenerateMipMapLevels
member.summary:
Regenerates the mip map levels of the texture.
Required in most cases after modifying the texture using the object returned by GetTexturePainter(). Regeneration of mip map levels done in next way: the main level (most detailed level: level 0) is left untoched, all other levels will get automatic regeneration. This means that if you use TexturePainter and draw on different mip map levels, propbably you should not call this method, since only level 0 will contain your unique changes.

member.name: T:IrrlichtLime.Video.TextureCreationFlag
member.summary: Enumeration of flags telling the video driver in which format textures should be created.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.TextureCreationFlag.AllowNonPower2
member.summary:
Allow the driver to use non power of 2 textures (non-POT).
Note: BurningsVideo can handle non-POT in 2D (GUI), but not in 3D.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.TextureCreationFlag.Always16Bit
member.summary:
Forces the driver to create 16 bit textures always, independent of which format the file on disk has. When choosing this you may loose some color detail, but gain much speed and less memory usage.
When using this flag, it does not make sense to use the flags Always32Bit, OptimizedForQuality or OptimizedForSpeed at the same time.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.TextureCreationFlag.Always32Bit
member.summary:
Forces the driver to create 32 bit textures always, independent of which format the file on disk has. Please note that some drivers (like the software device) will ignore this, because they are only able to create and use 16 bit textures.
When using this flag, it does not make sense to use the flags Always16Bit, OptimizedForQuality or OptimizedForSpeed at the same time.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.TextureCreationFlag.CreateMipMaps
member.summary: Automatically creates mip map levels for the textures.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.TextureCreationFlag.NoAlphaChannel
member.summary: Discard any alpha layer and use non-alpha color format.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.TextureCreationFlag.OptimizedForQuality
member.summary:
Lets the driver decide in which format the textures are created and tries to make the textures look as good as possible. Usually it simply chooses the format in which the texture was stored on disk.
When using this flag, it does not make sense to use the flags Always16Bit, Always32Bit, or OptimizedForSpeed at the same time.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.TextureCreationFlag.OptimizedForSpeed
member.summary:
Lets the driver decide in which format the textures are created and tries to create them maximizing render speed.
When using this flag, it does not make sense to use the flags Always16Bit, Always32Bit or OptimizedForQuality at the same time.

member.name: T:IrrlichtLime.Video.TextureLockMode
member.summary: Texture locking modes.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.TextureLockMode.ReadOnly
member.summary: Read only. The texture is downloaded, but not uploaded again.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.TextureLockMode.ReadWrite
member.summary: The default mode. Texture can be read and written to.

member.name: F:IrrlichtLime.Video.TextureLockMode.WriteOnly
member.summary: Write only. The texture is not downloaded and might be uninitialized.

member.name: T:IrrlichtLime.Video.TexturePainter
member.summary:
Provides ability to paint on texture's different mip map levels. Object of TexturePainter can be obtained using Texture.GetTexturePainter().
Order of usage: 1) get a Texture object; call its GetTexturePainter() and save the pointer. You can use this pointer until texture not dropped; 2) when you need access texture pixels, use Lock(), then read/write pixels, then Unlock().
Note: all the members in this class requires texture to be locked using Lock() before using them (except actually: Lock(), Texture, Locked and MipMapLevelCount).

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Video.TexturePainter.GetPixel(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets a single pixel from currently locked mip map level.
member.param: X coord. Must be less than MipMapLevelWidth.
Y coord. Must be less than MipMapLevelHeight.
member.returns: Color of the pixel.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Video.TexturePainter.Lock
member.summary: Locks mip map level 0 (main level) for reading and writing.
member.returns: True on success.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Video.TexturePainter.Lock(IrrlichtLime.Video.TextureLockMode)
member.summary: Locks mip map level 0 (main level) in specified mode.
member.param: Lock mode. Default: ReadWrite.
member.returns: True on success.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Video.TexturePainter.Lock(IrrlichtLime.Video.TextureLockMode,System.Int32)
member.summary: Locks specified mip map level in specified mode.
member.param: Lock mode. Default: ReadWrite.
Mip map level to lock. Must be less than MipMapLevelCount. Default: 0.
member.returns: True on success.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.TexturePainter.Locked
member.summary: True if Texture is locked and you can access the content of currently locked mip map level.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.TexturePainter.LockMode
member.summary: Lock mode currently used.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.TexturePainter.MipMapLevel
member.summary:
Currently locked mip map level.
Note: can be from 0 to MipMapLevelCount-1.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.TexturePainter.MipMapLevelCount
member.summary: Total number of mip map levels in the texture. This value depends on the size of the texture: larger textures has more mip map levels.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.TexturePainter.MipMapLevelHeight
member.summary:
Height of currently locked mip map level.
Note: if MipMapLevel == 0, then real height of the texture is stored here.

member.name: P:IrrlichtLime.Video.TexturePainter.MipMapLevelWidth
member.summary:
Width of currently locked mip map level.
Note: if MipMapLevel == 0, then real width of the texture is stored here.

member.summary: Draws a line on the currently locked mip map level.

Y1 coord. Must be less than MipMapLevelHeight.
X2 coord. Must be less than MipMapLevelWidth.
Y2 coord. Must be less than MipMapLevelHeight.
Color of the line.

member.summary: Sets a single pixel on currently locked mip map level.

Y coord. Must be less than MipMapLevelHeight.
Color of the pixel.

member.name: T:IrrlichtLime.Video.VertexPrimitive
member.summary: Incapsulates array of vertices and indices in native (unmanaged) form. This class uses native pointers and that's why it is able to draw primitives faster then direct calling to VideoDriver.DrawVertexPrimitiveList() in most cases.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Video.VertexPrimitive.Draw(IrrlichtLime.Video.VideoDriver)
member.summary: Draws vertex primitive using current driver's transformation and material.
member.param: Video driver to use.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Video.VertexPrimitive.Draw(IrrlichtLime.Video.VideoDriver,System.Int32)
member.summary: Draws vertex primitive using current driver's transformation and material.
member.param: Video driver to use.
Number of primitives to draw. This value should be less or equal to PrimitiveCount. If this value less than 1, the method will do nothing.

member.name: M:IrrlichtLime.Video.VertexPrimitive.Draw(IrrlichtLime.Video.VideoDriver,System.Int32,IrrlichtLime.Scene.PrimitiveType)
member.summary: Draws vertex primitive using current driver's transformation and material.
member.param: Video driver to use.
Number of primitives to draw. This value should be less or equal to PrimitiveCount. If this value less than 1, the method will do nothing.
Type of primitives to draw. This value must be compatible with IndexCount and overridePrimitiveCount values.

member.name: T:IrrlichtLime.Video.VideoDriver
member.summary:
Provides functionality to perform 2d and 3d graphics functions.
This class is one of the most important classes of the Irrlicht Lime: all rendering and texture manipulation is done with this class. You are able to use the Irrlicht Lime by only using methods of this class if you like to, although the SceneManager class provides a lot of powerful classes and methods to make the programmer's life easier.
